originalText.text: We have free kayaking over here. The area is a bit small but you can stay out for about a half hour paddling. The volunteers are awesome Pleasant people. üòÅ We have lockers and sunscreen also.

text.text: We have free kayaking over here. The area is a bit small but you can stay out for about a half hour paddling. The volunteers are awesome Pleasant people. üòÅ We have lockers and sunscreen also.

originalText.text: A great stop for a beginner kayaker or some one who has never been kayaking. It's free, the ppl in charge are very friendly, and they have solo & tandem kayaks. I'm a moderately experienced kayaker so I spiced it up a bit by racing around the cove with my siblings.  Lol it was a good time.

text.text: A great stop for a beginner kayaker or some one who has never been kayaking. It's free, the ppl in charge are very friendly, and they have solo & tandem kayaks. originalText.text: I volunteer here. They have free kayaking. It's a smaller area to kayak in than their other location in lower Manhattan (Pier 26) but it's still nice. Plus it's free so...

text.text: I volunteer here. They have free kayaking. It's a smaller area to kayak in than their other location in lower Manhattan (Pier 26) but it's still nice. Plus it's free so...

originalText.text: I've landed, launched or passed by here in a kayak or on a paddle board quite a few times. It used to be the busiest on annual City of Water Days, which were usu on or around the second weekend of July. On those days, a huge crowd of human-powered boaters, which included kayakers from many of the boathouses and clubs in the city including rowers of Whitehall Gigs (a few organizations in the city including Village Community Boathouse and Rocking the Boat in the South Bronx), outrigger canoe clubs and even canoeists would all arrive here under their own power. The groups included the original Downtown Boathouse (first in the city), Village Community Boathouse, Inwood Canoe Club, Yonkers Canoeing and Rowing, Sebago Canoe Club, Gowanus Dredgers, HarborLAB, Brooklyn Community Boathouse, Manhattan Community Boathouse, Ke Aloha Outriggers and others I'm sure I'm forgetting. Because the currents generally prevented everyone from both arriving and departing during daylight hours in one day we were allowed to camp on Governors Island overnight---the only night of the year anyone can do so. There is or before the pandemic, there was a regular free kayaking program here operated by the Downtown Boathouse. During a few years of City of Water Day, HarborLAB paddled its fleet here and did the same (I was a lifeguard on a number of those days). And these days to, the Harbor School and Billion Oyster Project use the docks as part of their operations too (a great organization!). This little place is one of the hubs of paddling in the city.

originalText.text: Volunteers are friendly.  Great free kayaking on Saturdays during the summer.
